{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3600283,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:14:42.251Z","cooked":"

I’ve been considering switching from 6 AWG wires to 4 AWG wires next season. We almost made the change this season, but decided against it because the effort needed to make the switch outweighed the benefits gained. I’d like to know why your teams use 4 AWG and if the effort it took to switch, like reworking your charging setup, was worth it for you.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T18:14:42.251Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":503,"readers_count":502,"score":260.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/1","custom_user_title":"862 Electrical Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3600290,"name":"MetabolicCloth","username":"MetabolicCloth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/metaboliccloth/{size}/9335_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:18:10.233Z","cooked":"

@sdtrent did a presentation at the championship about his teams experience. It’s worth a read/watch. He posted it in another topic on CD.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T18:18:10.233Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":492,"readers_count":491,"score":138.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"MetabolicCloth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33804,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600304,"name":"Battery Nerd - FRC #4561","username":"sdtrent","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/9de053/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:25:09.897Z","cooked":"

@MetabolicCloth

Thanks for the mention about the seminar!

@elctrilica The link below has notes on our journey changing to larger wire size while keeping the SB50 connectors, and all of our SB50 connected chargers, testers, etc. There are a couple of cautions, attention to detail is important when trimming the 2ga cable down to fit the system terminals, and PDH (see cautionary tale).

Write up on switching to 2ga with SB50 connectors

docs.google.com

2ga Battery Cables and TerrorByte Terminals

2ga Cable in SB50 and TerrorByte Terminals™ TerrorBytes FRC #4561 We want to share some of the power related improvements we are building into our REEFSCAPE robot build. One of our focus points this season is to improve the reliability of our power...

Slides from my Houston robot power presentation

docs.google.com

Robot Power Delivery: Maximizing Performance

Optimizing Robot Power Delivery Shane Trent Battery Nerd FRC #4561 TerrorBytes Presentation Video

And a link to the presentation video

Let me know if you have questions about anything we tried.

Thanks!
Shane

Google Slides","clicks":28},{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ydW08ZI_GMc","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":33804,"username":"MetabolicCloth","name":"MetabolicCloth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/metaboliccloth/{size}/9335_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54265,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Problem Solver"},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/3","custom_user_title":"Problem Solver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600310,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:26:17.848Z","cooked":"

It’s somewhat difficult to gauge for us this year since the power demands on our 2025 robot are significantly less than our 2024 robots were.

That being said, we switched over to 4AWG while still using the Anderson SB50 connectors for compatibility with older hardware, following the instructions on this paper: Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics

In general the 4AWG seems to be much more robust and results in a lower resistance of the system overall, plus modifying only the batteries Anderson lugs is somewhat cheaper than replacing all your SB50s (Batteries + Chargers + Robots); though as mentioned earlier, it would take a more power-taxing game to really know how much it improves your performance.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T18:29:08.109Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":397,"readers_count":396,"score":109.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://team2363.org/2017/05/using-4-awg-with-the-anderson-sb50/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics","clicks":13}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600553,"name":"David Kravets","username":"dak000","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T20:41:09.781Z","cooked":"

Does your power wire feel hot to the touch after a match? If yes, time to uprate that cabling

Ok… It’s not actually this simple, but it kind of is. Even our 4awg cable get’s pretty toasty after 2:30 of playing, so I can see why some teams are going 2awg (or even higher). On the contrary, if you aren’t running hot after a match, I’d say save the money and keep running 6awg

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T20:41:39.989Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":318,"readers_count":317,"score":128.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"David Kravets","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60836,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9072 mentor | don't waste electrons"},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/5","custom_user_title":"9072 mentor | don't waste electrons","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600585,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T21:06:28.537Z","cooked":"

4 AWG is the biggest that doesn’t require a lot of extra work. It feels like the right price/performance/annoyance trade off.

If you strip #4 and immediately (with NO twisting) stuff it into the SB50 #6 lugs it will go in. Start atban angle and swing into line! Usually just a few errant strands to clip.

I built and did the lug expansion, but found it just wasnt needed.

My measurements back a ways clearly showed the difference, matching up with the predictions quite well. Note that the breakers and the copper in the power panel become important at this level!

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T21:06:28.537Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":274,"readers_count":273,"score":119.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600670,"name":"Tanmay Darji","username":"TanmayD","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tanmayd/{size}/238655_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T22:24:22.830Z","cooked":"

If you do switch over to 4awg might I recommend the windynation welding wire. It somehow fits perfectly into the sb50 crimps without too much effort and is very flexible which is something our drive team prizes. Amazing to work with.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T22:24:22.830Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":220,"readers_count":219,"score":44.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"Tanmay Darji","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600712,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T23:23:43.419Z","cooked":"

It depends on where your team is on the robot performance curve, and how much budget you have to spend on this.

~90% of teams don’t need to worry about it. Get your drive gearing correct (maybe go a little conservative on it, in the SDS system stick to L2), get your superstructure gearing a little conservative, and focus on good process around your battery terminations, protecting the wire paths to your terminal lugs, etc. Put budget and process work into good practices that help you avoid catastrophic failure, rather than into +3% marginal gains. If you change over to 4awg here, it’s a philosophical choice that should be coupled with all the other battery process changes (protect lugs from side load, bolt connector to chassis, etc). 841 went to 4awg in 2019 as part of a full suite of best practices updates after catastrophic reliability failures in 2018. Think big sparks and robot stops level of catastrophic.

Bottom line: a loose lug with 4awg in it is just as catastrophic as a loose lug with 6awg.

~9% of teams, that already are measuring robot actions to tenths of seconds, and spending hundreds of dollars on racks of fresh batteries, and already build custom main power runs, should have 4awg in SB50s on the list of little optimizations to chase. It’s honestly not hard to do, and it’s worth a couple % more power before you hit brownout. We ran it from 2019-2024, didn’t worry about it this year on the Robot side due to less aggressive drive gearing and shorter sprint distances. Also didn’t habitually brown out this year.

Bottom line: yes, 4awg main power is a relatively easy marginal gain, but by no means required to succeed

(The last ~1% of teams could run SB120’s for an extra 1% of performance.)

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T23:38:51.992Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":186,"readers_count":185,"score":112.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600744,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T00:02:16.934Z","cooked":"

People have said it above but 4awg wire, SB120, etc are all marginal performance gains. They won’t win you any matches on their own. For most teams that means their resources are better spent elsewhere.

Personally I believe buying 8 new batteries every season and having enough quality chargers to maintain them and your practice batteries will be a much better investment for most teams. If you’re already doing that and already have short main wire paths, super secure battery and main breaker bolted connections, etc. Then maybe upgrading to 4 awg is maybe worth it.

In general you have to determine how much benefit for the cost is worth it to your team.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T00:02:16.934Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":152.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/9","custom_user_title":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600769,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T00:26:41.000Z","cooked":"
AllenGregoryIV:

Personally I believe buying 8 new batteries every season and having enough quality chargers to maintain them and your practice batteries will be a much better investment for most teams.

Personally, I treat this as a given. Our batteries are basically all one-season only, and become practice batteries after that. I’ve even heard of teams that replace all their batteries multiple times a season. FRC kills these batteries, they’re really not designed to take the abuse we throw at them.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T00:27:15.988Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":22.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500174,"topic_slug":"is-4-awg-wire-worth-it","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-4-awg-wire-worth-it/500174/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600772,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T00:28:31.888Z","cooked":"
Weldingrod1:

I built and did the lug expansion, but found it just wasnt needed.

This year I used a Banebot wheel hub with set screw holding the flat end loosely, arbor press and 1/4" pin for expanding SB50 terminals which worked surprisingly well and students could do it easily.

I definitely feel that in games like last year that 4awg was helpful. This year we probably would have been okay without.

As said that I don’t think wire gauge is that high on list of doing things for battery. Here were my order from battery presentation at Massive Mini and it was the last things.

Screenshot_2025-04-22-19-31-00-816706×339 80.6 KB

Here is the rest of it. FRC Battery Practices - Google Slides

I am interested to check out the conference talk about and incorporate any more knowledge for this year.
